topics.title: Attribution Theory
topics.subtitle: How We Explain Behavior
topics.summary: Attribution theory explores how people explain the causes of behavior, both their own and others'. Three classic theories form the foundation: Heider's Naïve Scientist Theory, Jones & Davis's Correspondence Inference Theory, and Kelley's Covariation Theory.
keyTakeaways: Attributions can be internal (dispositional) or external (situational), affecting how we interpret behavior.
Heider proposed that people act as 'naïve scientists' who seek causal explanations for events.
Kelley's Covariation Theory uses consensus, distinctiveness, and consistency to determine attributions.
Attribution biases like the Fundamental Attribution Error lead to systematic errors in judgment.

content.text: What is Attribution?
An attribution is an explanation for the causes of behavior, whether our own or others'. Psychologists distinguish between two main types of attributions:

content.title: Types of Attributions
items: Internal (Dispositional) Attribution: Behavior is explained by something inside the person, such as personality, intelligence, or motivation.
External (Situational) Attribution: Behavior is explained by something outside the person, such as luck, task difficulty, or environmental factors.

content.text: Heider's Naïve Scientist Theory (1958)

Fritz Heider proposed that people act as 'naïve scientists' who use rational processes to explain events in their social world. In the famous Heider and Simmel (1944) experiment, participants watched geometric shapes move around and attributed personality traits, intentions, and emotions to these inanimate objects—demonstrating our inherent drive to seek causal explanations.

content.title: Classic Study
content.text: When college students watched abstract geometric shapes moving in and out of a rectangle, they systematically interpreted the shapes as persons with specific personality traits, needs, and dispositions like aggression or fear, showing that we automatically seek causal explanations even for inanimate objects.
Jones & Davis: Correspondence Inference Theory (1965)
This theory explains how we infer that a person's behavior corresponds to their underlying disposition or personality. Two key factors influence correspondent inferences:

content.title: Factors in Correspondent Inference
items: Intentionality: We are more likely to make dispositional attributions when behavior appears intentional rather than unintentional. The person must know the consequences and have the ability to perform the action.

Social Desirability: We are more likely to attribute behavior to disposition when the effects are socially undesirable. For example, if someone is very rude in a social situation, we conclude they are an unpleasant person.

content.text: Kelley's Covariation Theory (1967, 1973)
Harold Kelley proposed that when we have multiple observations of a person's behavior, we use three types of information to determine whether to make internal or external attributions:

content.title: Three Dimensions of Covariation
items: Consensus: Do other people behave the same way in response to this stimulus? High consensus = others act similarly; Low consensus = others act differently.
Distinctiveness: Does the person behave this way in other situations? High distinctiveness = behavior is unique to this situation; Low distinctiveness = person behaves this way in most situations.
Consistency: Does the person respond this way across time? High consistency = person always behaves this way; Low consistency = this is unusual behavior for this person.

content.title: Example: Sarah Fails Her PSYC100 Exam
content.text: Distinctiveness: High = failed only this exam; Low = failed other exams. Consistency: High = failed exams before; Low = rarely failed before. Consensus: High = other students failed this exam; Low = few others failed. High consensus + high distinctiveness + high consistency = External attribution (the exam was hard). Low consensus + low distinctiveness + high consistency = Internal attribution (Sarah lacks ability).

questions.question: According to Heider's Naïve Scientist Theory, what do people naturally seek when observing behavior?
options: Emotional validation
Causal explanations
Social approval
Behavioral predictions
questions.answer: Causal explanations

explanation.correct: Heider proposed that people act as naïve scientists who use rational processes to seek causal explanations for events, even attributing intentions to inanimate objects.

incorrect.Emotional validation: While people may seek emotional validation, Heider's theory specifically focuses on the cognitive process of seeking causal explanations.
incorrect.Social approval: Social approval relates more to conformity and normative influence, not attribution processes.
incorrect.Behavioral predictions: While predictions may follow from attributions, the theory emphasizes the search for causes, not predictions.

questions.question: In the Heider and Simmel (1944) study, participants watched geometric shapes move and attributed what to them?
options: Physical properties only
Random movements
Personality traits and intentions
Mathematical patterns
questions.answer: Personality traits and intentions

explanation.correct: Participants systematically interpreted the shapes as persons with personality traits, needs, and dispositions like aggression or fear, demonstrating our inherent drive to seek causal explanations.

incorrect.Physical properties only: Participants went beyond physical properties to attribute psychological characteristics to the shapes.
incorrect.Random movements: Participants did not see the movements as random but as intentional and meaningful.
incorrect.Mathematical patterns: The study focused on social-psychological interpretations, not mathematical analysis.

questions.question: According to Jones & Davis's Correspondence Inference Theory, when are we most likely to make dispositional attributions?
options: When behavior is unintentional and socially desirable
When behavior is intentional and socially undesirable
When behavior is unintentional and socially undesirable
When behavior is intentional and socially desirable
questions.answer: When behavior is intentional and socially undesirable

explanation.correct: We are most likely to infer a correspondence between behavior and disposition when the behavior appears intentional AND when its effects are socially undesirable, as this reveals something unique about the person.

incorrect.When behavior is unintentional and socia: Unintentional behavior does not allow us to infer much about disposition, and socially desirable behavior could be due to social norms.
Unintentional behavior makes it difficult to infer dispositional causes regardless of social desirability.
incorrect.When behavior is intentional and sociall: Socially desirable behavior could simply reflect conformity to norms rather than revealing underlying disposition.

questions.question: In Kelley's Covariation Theory, what does HIGH consensus indicate?
options: The person behaves this way across different situations
Other people behave the same way in this situation
The person consistently behaves this way over time
The behavior is socially desirable
questions.answer: Other people behave the same way in this situation

explanation.correct: High consensus means that other people respond similarly to the same stimulus or situation, suggesting the cause may be external (situational) rather than internal to the individual.

incorrect.The person behaves this way across diffe: This describes low distinctiveness, not consensus.
incorrect.The person consistently behaves this way: This describes high consistency, not consensus.
incorrect.The behavior is socially desirable: Social desirability is part of Jones & Davis's theory, not Kelley's covariation dimensions.

questions.question: Sarah fails her PSYC100 exam. If the failure shows HIGH consensus, HIGH distinctiveness, and HIGH consistency, what attribution would be made?
options: Internal attribution: Sarah lacks ability
External attribution: The exam was difficult
Internal attribution: Sarah didn't study
External attribution: The professor grades unfairly
questions.answer: External attribution: The exam was difficult

explanation.correct: High consensus (others failed too) + high distinctiveness (Sarah only failed this exam) + high consistency (Sarah has failed similar exams before) leads to an external attribution—the exam was objectively difficult.

incorrect.Internal attribution: Sarah lacks abilit: This would require LOW consensus (only Sarah failed), LOW distinctiveness (Sarah fails many exams), and HIGH consistency.
incorrect.Internal attribution: Sarah didn't study: While possible, the high consensus and high distinctiveness pattern points more strongly to situational factors.
incorrect.External attribution: The professor grad: While external, the specific pattern (high on all three dimensions) most directly suggests task difficulty.

questions.question: What does LOW distinctiveness indicate in Kelley's model?
options: The person behaves this way in most situations
Other people rarely behave this way
The person rarely behaves this way
The behavior is very distinctive
questions.answer: The person behaves this way in most situations

explanation.correct: Low distinctiveness means the behavior is typical across many situations for this person, suggesting an internal (dispositional) attribution rather than something specific to this situation.

incorrect.Other people rarely behave this way: This describes low consensus, not distinctiveness.
incorrect.The person rarely behaves this way: This would be high distinctiveness, indicating the behavior is unique to this situation.
incorrect.The behavior is very distinctive: This is the opposite—low distinctiveness means the behavior is NOT distinctive to this situation.

questions.question: A student always arrives late to all classes, not just psychology. Other students arrive on time, and the student has been late consistently all semester. What attribution is most appropriate?
options: External: The class schedule is inconvenient
Internal: The student has poor time management
External: The campus is difficult to navigate
Internal: The student dislikes this professor
questions.answer: Internal: The student has poor time management

explanation.correct: This shows LOW consensus (others arrive on time), LOW distinctiveness (late to all classes), and HIGH consistency (always late). This pattern strongly suggests an internal attribution about the student's characteristics.

incorrect.External: The class schedule is inconven: If the schedule were the problem, we'd expect high consensus (others would also be late), which we don't see.
incorrect.External: The campus is difficult to nav: Again, if this were true, we'd expect high consensus (many students late), but only this student is consistently late.
incorrect.Internal: The student dislikes this prof: The low distinctiveness (late to ALL classes) rules out this specific explanation—it's not about one professor.

questions.question: Sarah fails her PSYC100 exam. According to Kelley's Covariation Theory, which combination of information would lead you to make an internal (dispositional) attribution about Sarah?
options: High consensus (many students failed), high distinctiveness (Sarah only failed this exam), high consistency (Sarah often fails exams)
Low consensus (few students failed), low distinctiveness (Sarah failed other exams too), high consistency (Sarah often fails exams)
High consensus (many students failed), low distinctiveness (Sarah failed other exams too), low consistency (Sarah rarely fails exams)
Low consensus (few students failed), high distinctiveness (Sarah only failed this exam), low consistency (Sarah rarely fails exams)
questions.answer: Low consensus (few students failed), low distinctiveness (Sarah failed other exams too), high consistency (Sarah often fails exams)

explanation.correct: This combination points to internal attribution. Low consensus suggests Sarah's behavior is unusual compared to others. Low distinctiveness indicates the behavior generalizes across situations (she fails multiple exams, not just this one). High consistency shows the pattern repeats over time. Together, these suggest the cause is something about Sarah herself (e.g., study habits, ability) rather than external factors.

incorrect.High consensus (many students failed), h: High consensus and high distinctiveness would lead to external attribution (blaming the exam itself), not internal attribution about Sarah.
incorrect.High consensus (many students failed), l: High consensus suggests an external cause (the exam was difficult for everyone), which contradicts internal attribution.
incorrect.Low consensus (few students failed), hig: High distinctiveness and low consistency would lead to external attribution (something unique about this particular exam situation), not internal.

questions.question: In Ross et al.'s (1977) Quiz Game Study, contestants and observers rated questioners as significantly more knowledgeable than contestants, even though questioners had the unfair advantage of creating their own questions. This demonstrates which attribution error?
options: False Consensus Effect
Self-Serving Bias
Fundamental Attribution Error
Actor-Observer Effect
questions.answer: Fundamental Attribution Error

explanation.correct: This is the Fundamental Attribution Error - the tendency to overemphasize dispositional (personality-based) explanations while underestimating situational influences. Participants attributed the questioner's advantage to superior general knowledge (dispositional) rather than to their role advantage of creating questions (situational).

incorrect.False Consensus Effect: False Consensus Effect involves overestimating how many others share your views/behaviors, not about attribution of others' abilities.
incorrect.Self-Serving Bias: Self-Serving Bias is about how we explain our own successes (internal) vs failures (external), not about judging others.
incorrect.Actor-Observer Effect: Actor-Observer Effect involves differences in how we explain our own behavior (situational) vs others' behavior (dispositional), but this study specifically demonstrates the general tendency to ignore situational factors when judging others.

questions.question: According to Jones & Davis's Correspondence Inference Theory, when are we MOST likely to make a dispositional attribution about someone's personality?
options: When their behavior appears unintentional and is socially desirable
When their behavior appears intentional and is socially desirable
When their behavior appears unintentional and is socially undesirable
When their behavior appears intentional and is socially undesirable
questions.answer: When their behavior appears intentional and is socially undesirable

explanation.correct: We make the strongest correspondent inference (dispositional attribution) when behavior appears intentional AND socially undesirable. If someone is very rude intentionally, we conclude they are an unpleasant person because there's no social pressure to behave that way - it must reflect their true disposition.

incorrect.When their behavior appears unintentiona: Unintentional behavior doesn't reveal personality. Socially desirable behavior could be due to social pressure, not true disposition.
incorrect.When their behavior appears intentional: Socially desirable behavior might just reflect social pressure/norms rather than true personality, making it weak evidence for dispositional attribution.
incorrect.When their behavior appears unintentiona: Unintentional behavior doesn't tell us much about personality since the person didn't choose to act that way.

questions.question: In the Jones & Harris (1967) Castro Study, participants were told that speech makers were assigned their pro-Castro or anti-Castro position by a coin flip. Despite knowing this, participants still rated pro-Castro speakers as having more positive attitudes toward Castro. This demonstrates:
options: Self-Serving Bias - participants were protecting their own political views
Fundamental Attribution Error - participants ignored the situational constraint of the coin flip
False Consensus Effect - participants assumed others shared their views about Castro
Actor-Observer Effect - participants viewed themselves differently than the speakers
questions.answer: Fundamental Attribution Error - participants ignored the situational constraint of the coin flip

explanation.correct: This is a classic demonstration of the Fundamental Attribution Error. Even when explicitly told that the speech position was determined by a coin flip (a clear situational factor), participants still made dispositional attributions about the speakers' actual attitudes toward Castro. They underestimated the situational constraint and overemphasized dispositional factors.

incorrect.Self-Serving Bias - participants were pr: Self-Serving Bias is about explaining one's own successes/failures, not about judging others' attitudes.
incorrect.False Consensus Effect - participants as: False Consensus Effect is about overestimating agreement with your own views, not about attributing attitudes based on assigned speeches.
incorrect.Actor-Observer Effect - participants vie: Actor-Observer Effect is about explaining your own behavior (situational) vs others' (dispositional), but this study focuses on the general tendency to ignore situational constraints.

questions.question: A student says 'I got 90 for my essay!' but later says 'The lecturer gave me 40!' This exemplifies which attribution bias?
options: Fundamental Attribution Error
False Consensus Effect
Self-Serving Bias
Actor-Observer Effect
questions.answer: Self-Serving Bias

explanation.correct: This is Self-Serving Bias - taking credit for success (internal attribution: 'I got 90') while denying responsibility for failure (external attribution: 'The lecturer gave me 40'). We do this to protect and enhance self-esteem.

incorrect.Fundamental Attribution Error: FAE is about judging others' behavior (overemphasizing dispositional factors), not about explaining our own outcomes.
incorrect.False Consensus Effect: False Consensus Effect involves overestimating how many others share your views/behaviors, not about explaining successes and failures.
incorrect.Actor-Observer Effect: While related, Actor-Observer Effect is specifically about the difference between explaining your own actions (situational) vs others' actions (dispositional), not specifically about success/failure attributions.

questions.question: In Ross et al.'s (1977) False Consensus Effect study, participants were asked if they would wear a sign around campus. What did researchers find?
options: Participants who agreed to wear the sign estimated 23% of others would, while those who refused estimated 77% would refuse
Participants who agreed to wear the sign estimated 63% of others would, while those who refused estimated 77% would refuse
All participants accurately estimated that 50% would agree and 50% would refuse
Participants who refused to wear the sign were more accurate in their estimates than those who agreed
questions.answer: Participants who agreed to wear the sign estimated 63% of others would, while those who refused estimated 77% would refuse

explanation.correct: This demonstrates the False Consensus Effect - participants overestimated how many others would behave as they did. Those who said 'yes' thought 63% would agree (actual was 50%), and those who said 'no' thought 77% would refuse (actual was 50%). Each group saw their own choice as more typical than it actually was.

incorrect.Participants who agreed to wear the sign: These percentages are reversed. The 23% estimate came from the refuse group estimating how many would agree.
incorrect.All participants accurately estimated th: This contradicts the False Consensus Effect - participants were not accurate, they overestimated consensus with their own choice.
incorrect.Participants who refused to wear the sig: Both groups showed the bias equally - both overestimated consensus with their own position.

questions.question: According to the Actor-Observer Effect described by Jones & Nisbett (1972), how would you likely explain why YOU gave a bad presentation versus why YOUR CLASSMATE gave a bad presentation?
options: Your presentation: lack of preparation (internal); Classmate's presentation: too many competing deadlines (external)
Your presentation: too many competing deadlines (external); Classmate's presentation: poor public speaking skills (internal)
Both: dispositional factors like intelligence and preparation
Both: situational factors like time pressure and technical difficulties
questions.answer: Your presentation: too many competing deadlines (external); Classmate's presentation: poor public speaking skills (internal)

explanation.correct: This demonstrates the Actor-Observer Effect. As the actor, you attribute your own bad presentation to situational factors (external): 'I had three other projects due, my computer crashed.' As an observer, you attribute your classmate's bad presentation to dispositional factors (internal): 'they don't know the subject well, lack intelligence, or are terrible at public speaking.'

incorrect.Your presentation: lack of preparation (: This is the opposite of the Actor-Observer Effect. We tend to be more lenient with ourselves (situational) and harsher on others (dispositional).
incorrect.Both: dispositional factors like intelli: This ignores the actor-observer distinction - we don't typically attribute our own failures to dispositional factors.
incorrect.Both: situational factors like time pres: While we might use situational explanations for our own behavior, we typically don't extend the same consideration to others' behavior.

questions.question: Sherif's (1935) Autokinetic Effect study and Asch's (1950s) Line study both demonstrate conformity, but through different mechanisms. What is the key difference?
options: Sherif's study shows normative influence leading to compliance; Asch's shows informational influence leading to internalization
Sherif's study shows informational influence leading to internalization; Asch's shows normative influence leading to compliance
Both studies demonstrate normative influence, but Sherif's task was harder
Both studies demonstrate informational influence, but Asch's involved more peer pressure
questions.answer: Sherif's study shows informational influence leading to internalization; Asch's shows normative influence leading to compliance

explanation.correct: Sherif used an ambiguous task (autokinetic effect - light appears to move in darkness). Participants relied on others for information about the 'correct' answer (informational influence) and genuinely changed their beliefs (internalization). Asch used an unambiguous task (clearly different line lengths). Participants knew the correct answer but conformed due to fear of social disapproval (normative influence) without truly believing the wrong answer (compliance).

incorrect.Sherif's study shows normative influence: This is backwards. The ambiguous task (Sherif) produces informational influence, while the clear task with social pressure (Asch) produces normative influence.
incorrect.Both studies demonstrate normative influ: Sherif's study demonstrates informational influence (not normative) because the task was ambiguous and participants genuinely didn't know the answer.
incorrect.Both studies demonstrate informational i: Asch's study demonstrates normative influence (social pressure), not informational influence, because the task was unambiguous - participants knew the right answer.

questions.question: In Milgram's (1974) obedience experiment, what percentage of participants administered the maximum 450-volt shock, and what percentage stopped before the 300-volt level?
options: 45% went to 450V; 15% stopped before 300V
65% went to 450V; 0% stopped before 300V
25% went to 450V; 30% stopped before 300V
85% went to 450V; 5% stopped before 300V
questions.answer: 65% went to 450V; 0% stopped before 300V

explanation.correct: Milgram's shocking finding was that 65% (26 out of 40) of participants administered the full 450-volt shock, and NO participant stopped before the 300-volt level (though many were uncomfortable). This was far higher than the predictions from psychologists, who thought only sadists would go to maximum voltage. The average was 360 volts.

incorrect.45% went to 450V; 15% stopped before 300: These percentages are too low. Milgram found much higher obedience rates than anyone expected.
incorrect.25% went to 450V; 30% stopped before 300: These percentages dramatically underestimate the obedience found. The actual results were much more disturbing.
incorrect.85% went to 450V; 5% stopped before 300V: While obedience was high, 65% (not 85%) went to maximum, and absolutely no one stopped before 300V (not 5%).

questions.question: Heider & Simmel (1944) showed college students abstract geometric figures moving in and out of a rectangle. Participants systematically interpreted the shapes as having personalities and intentions (e.g., aggression, escape). This supports which aspect of attribution theory?
options: People only make attributions about human behavior, not inanimate objects
People give causal attributions even to inanimate objects and perceive behavior as being caused
External attributions are more common than internal attributions
People use the covariation principle to analyze geometric shapes
questions.answer: People give causal attributions even to inanimate objects and perceive behavior as being caused

explanation.correct: This study demonstrated Heider's idea that people are 'naive scientists' who perceive behavior as being caused and make causal attributions even to inanimate objects. Participants attributed personalities, intentions, and dispositions to simple geometric shapes, showing our fundamental tendency to seek causal explanations for all observed movement/behavior.

incorrect.People only make attributions about huma: This directly contradicts the study's findings - participants readily attributed intentions to geometric shapes.
incorrect.External attributions are more common th: The study wasn't about the relative frequency of internal vs external attributions, but about our tendency to attribute causality at all, even to non-humans.
incorrect.People use the covariation principle to: The study demonstrates basic causal attribution tendencies (Heider's theory), not Kelley's specific covariation model which involves consensus, distinctiveness, and consistency.

questions.question: What is the primary distinction between internalization and compliance in conformity?
options: Internalization occurs in ambiguous situations; compliance occurs in clear situations
Internalization involves public agreement but private disagreement; compliance involves both public and private acceptance
Internalization involves changing real thoughts and feelings; compliance involves public agreement without internal acceptance
Internalization results from authority pressure; compliance results from peer pressure
questions.answer: Internalization involves changing real thoughts and feelings; compliance involves both public and private acceptance

explanation.correct: Internalization means you actually change your real beliefs and feelings (public response = private acceptance), often due to informational influence. Compliance means you publicly agree but privately maintain your original beliefs (public response ≠ private acceptance), often due to normative influence and desire for social approval.

incorrect.Internalization occurs in ambiguous situ: While this describes typical contexts (Sherif vs Asch), it's not the defining distinction. The key difference is whether private beliefs change.
incorrect.Internalization involves public agreemen: This is backwards. Internalization means private acceptance (you really believe it), while compliance means public agreement without private acceptance.
incorrect.Internalization results from authority p: Both can result from peer pressure. The distinction is about whether internal beliefs change, not the source of pressure.

questions.question: In Asch's line study, 37% of participants gave incorrect responses when confederates unanimously gave wrong answers. Participants showed extreme discomfort. What does this demonstrate?
options: Informational influence in an ambiguous task
Normative influence and fear of social disapproval in an unambiguous task
The Actor-Observer Effect in group settings
False Consensus Effect when making perceptual judgments
questions.answer: Normative influence and fear of social disapproval in an unambiguous task

explanation.correct: Asch's study used an unambiguous task (the correct line was obvious - 35/37 control participants got it right). The conformity and extreme discomfort demonstrate normative influence: participants conformed due to fear of social disapproval, not because they thought the group was correct. This produces compliance (public conformity) without internalization (private belief).

incorrect.Informational influence in an ambiguous: Asch's task was unambiguous (obvious correct answer), not ambiguous. Informational influence occurs when the task is unclear and you rely on others for information.
incorrect.The Actor-Observer Effect in group setti: The Actor-Observer Effect is about attribution (explaining behavior as actor vs observer), not about conformity to group pressure.
incorrect.False Consensus Effect when making perce: False Consensus Effect involves overestimating agreement with your position, not conforming to an obviously incorrect group judgment.

questions.question: Which factor has been shown to REDUCE conformity in group settings?
options: Increasing the group size from 3 to 15 people
Having the group consist of people from collectivistic cultures
Having just one person in the group disagree with the others
Making the task more ambiguous
questions.answer: Having just one person in the group disagree with the others

explanation.correct: The presence of a dissenter (even one person disagreeing with the group) greatly reduces conformity. This breaks the unanimity of the group and gives the participant social support for non-conformity, making it easier to resist group pressure.

incorrect.Increasing the group size from 3 to 15 p: Increasing group size actually increases conformity (though the effect plateaus after about 4-5 people).
incorrect.Having the group consist of people from: Collectivistic cultures show greater conformity than individualistic cultures, so this would increase, not reduce, conformity.
incorrect.Making the task more ambiguous: Ambiguous tasks increase conformity through informational influence (people rely more on others when uncertain).

questions.question: A student explains 'I chose engineering because it's a high-paying field' (situational), but explains 'My friend chose engineering because he wants to make lots of money' (dispositional). This pattern from Nisbett et al. (1973) demonstrates:
options: Fundamental Attribution Error
Self-Serving Bias
Actor-Observer Effect
False Consensus Effect
questions.answer: Actor-Observer Effect

explanation.correct: This perfectly demonstrates the Actor-Observer Effect. When explaining your own behavior (actor role), you emphasize situational factors ('the field is high-paying'). When explaining your friend's same behavior (observer role), you attribute it to their disposition ('he wants to make money'). Same behavior, different explanations based on perspective.

incorrect.Fundamental Attribution Error: While related, FAE is the general tendency to overemphasize dispositional factors when explaining others' behavior. Actor-Observer Effect is more specific: the contrast between how we explain our own (situational) vs others' (dispositional) behavior.
incorrect.Self-Serving Bias: Self-Serving Bias is specifically about taking credit for success (internal) and denying responsibility for failure (external), not about explaining behavioral choices.
incorrect.False Consensus Effect: False Consensus Effect is about overestimating how many others share your views/behaviors, not about the attribution differences between actor and observer perspectives.

questions.question: Hofling et al.'s (1966) nurse study and Sheridan & King's (1972) puppy study serve what purpose in relation to Milgram's obedience research?
options: They show that obedience only occurs in artificial laboratory settings
They demonstrate obedience in more ecologically valid, real-world settings with actual consequences
They prove that people are more obedient to authority in medical settings than in other contexts
They show that Milgram's results were inflated due to participants knowing the shocks weren't real
questions.answer: They demonstrate obedience in more ecologically valid, real-world settings with actual consequences

explanation.correct: These were 'less artificial studies' that addressed criticisms of Milgram's lab-based research. Hofling's nurse study involved real nurses in real hospitals being asked to give potentially lethal injections (21/22 complied), showing high ecological validity. Sheridan & King had participants give REAL electric shocks to a puppy (not simulated). Both demonstrated that high obedience rates aren't just laboratory artifacts.

incorrect.They show that obedience only occurs in: These studies show the opposite - obedience occurs in real-world settings too, not just artificial labs.
incorrect.They prove that people are more obedient: While Hofling used a medical setting, the purpose wasn't to compare settings but to establish ecological validity. Sheridan used a non-medical learning task setting.
incorrect.They show that Milgram's results were in: These studies actually support Milgram's findings. Sheridan & King used real shocks and still found high obedience, validating rather than contradicting Milgram.

questions.question: Zimbardo's Stanford Prison Experiment (1973) was planned to last 2 weeks but ended after only 6 days. What did this study demonstrate?
options: That individual personality traits are the primary determinant of behavior in group settings
The power of social situations and assigned roles on people's behavior, showing aspects of conformity and obedience
That people with aggressive personalities should not be given authority positions
That prison environments have no effect on normal individuals' behavior
questions.answer: The power of social situations and assigned roles on people's behavior, showing aspects of conformity and obedience

explanation.correct: The SPE demonstrated the power of social situations on behavior. Normal college students assigned to 'guard' roles quickly became authoritarian and harsh, while those assigned as 'prisoners' showed passive submission and anxiety. The study was stopped early due to ethical concerns over escalating abuse. This shows how situational forces and role expectations can dramatically alter behavior, demonstrating conformity, obedience, and situational influence.

incorrect.That individual personality traits are t: The study showed the opposite - situational factors (assigned roles) were more powerful than individual personality differences in determining behavior.
incorrect.That people with aggressive personalitie: Participants were normal college students randomly assigned to roles. The study showed situational power, not pre-existing personality differences.
incorrect.That prison environments have no effect: The study showed dramatic effects - guards became abusive, prisoners showed distress, leading to early termination due to ethical concerns.

questions.question: Tom laughs hysterically at a comedy show. High consensus: everyone is laughing. High distinctiveness: Tom doesn't usually laugh at shows. High consistency: Tom laughed at this comedian before. According to Kelley's Covariation Theory, you would attribute Tom's laughter to:
options: Something about Tom (internal attribution) - he's an especially cheerful person
Something about the comedian (external attribution) - the comedian is particularly funny
Something about the audience (external attribution) - the crowd is influencing him
A combination of Tom's personality and the situation
questions.answer: Something about the comedian (external attribution) - the comedian is particularly funny

explanation.correct: This combination (high consensus + high distinctiveness + high consistency) leads to external attribution about the stimulus (comedian). Everyone laughs (high consensus), Tom doesn't usually laugh at shows (high distinctiveness - this comedian is special), and Tom consistently responds this way to this comedian (high consistency). The behavior covaries with this specific comedian, suggesting the comedian is the cause.

incorrect.Something about Tom (internal attributio: High distinctiveness contradicts this - if it were about Tom's personality, he would laugh at all comedy shows (low distinctiveness), not just this one.
incorrect.Something about the audience (external a: While consensus is high, the high distinctiveness and consistency point specifically to the comedian as the cause, not general crowd influence.
incorrect.A combination of Tom's personality and t: Kelley's model uses this pattern to make a clear external attribution to the stimulus. High consensus + high distinctiveness + high consistency specifically indicates the entity (comedian) is the cause.

questions.question: In Kelley's Covariation Theory, 'consistency' refers to:
options: Whether other people behave the same way in response to the stimulus
Whether the behavior generalizes to other similar situations
Whether the person's response remains the same across time in this situation
Whether the behavior is socially appropriate given the context
questions.answer: Whether the person's response remains the same across time in this situation

explanation.correct: Consistency is the generality of behavior across time. High consistency means the individual always behaves this way in this situation (the behavior has been seen before). Low consistency means this is a new, unusual behavior for this person in this situation. It answers: 'How has the person responded previously to this situation?'

incorrect.Whether other people behave the same way: This describes consensus, not consistency. Consensus is about whether others behave similarly.
incorrect.Whether the behavior generalizes to othe: This describes distinctiveness, not consistency. Distinctiveness is about whether the behavior occurs in other situations or is unique to this one.
incorrect.Whether the behavior is socially appropr: This relates to Jones & Davis's Correspondence Inference Theory (social desirability), not Kelley's consistency dimension.

questions.question: Which of the following scenarios would most likely result in EXTERNAL attribution according to Kelley's Covariation Theory?
options: Low consensus, low distinctiveness, high consistency
High consensus, high distinctiveness, high consistency
Low consensus, high distinctiveness, low consistency
High consensus, low distinctiveness, low consistency
questions.answer: High consensus, high distinctiveness, high consistency

explanation.correct: High consensus (everyone acts this way), high distinctiveness (the behavior is unique to this situation), and high consistency (it happens repeatedly) all point to something about the external stimulus/situation causing the behavior. For example, if Sarah fails an exam (high consensus: everyone failed, high distinctiveness: she passes other exams, high consistency: this exam is consistently difficult), we attribute it to the exam being hard (external), not Sarah's ability.

incorrect.Low consensus, low distinctiveness, high: This pattern leads to internal attribution. The person behaves differently from others (low consensus), the behavior generalizes across situations (low distinctiveness), and it's consistent over time - suggesting something about the person.
incorrect.Low consensus, high distinctiveness, low: This combination is ambiguous but might suggest an unusual circumstance. It doesn't show the clear external attribution pattern.
incorrect.High consensus, low distinctiveness, low: Low consistency undermines attribution. If the behavior is inconsistent, it's hard to identify a stable cause, whether internal or external.

questions.question: A key difference between informational and normative social influence is:
options: Informational influence occurs in collectivistic cultures; normative influence occurs in individualistic cultures
Informational influence involves desire to be correct in ambiguous situations; normative influence involves desire to be liked and accepted
Informational influence affects men more than women; normative influence affects women more than men
Informational influence requires a large group; normative influence can occur with just one other person
questions.answer: Informational influence involves desire to be correct in ambiguous situations; normative influence involves desire to be liked and accepted

explanation.correct: Informational influence occurs when the situation is ambiguous and you rely on others for information to be correct (Sherif's autokinetic study). Normative influence occurs when you conform to be liked and avoid social disapproval, even when the situation is clear (Asch's line study). The key distinction is motivation: accuracy vs social acceptance.

incorrect.Informational influence occurs in collec: Both types of influence occur in all cultures, though collectivistic cultures may show more conformity overall.
incorrect.Informational influence affects men more: Gender differences in conformity are not the defining distinction between these two types of social influence.
incorrect.Informational influence requires a large: Both types can occur with varying group sizes. The distinction is about motivation and task ambiguity, not group size.

topics.title: Attribution Biases and Errors
topics.subtitle: Systematic Mistakes in Social Judgment
topics.summary: Despite our sophisticated attribution processes, people make systematic errors in judgment. Key biases include the Fundamental Attribution Error, False Consensus Effect, Self-Serving Bias, and Actor-Observer Effect.
keyTakeaways: The Fundamental Attribution Error is the tendency to overemphasize dispositional factors and underemphasize situational factors when explaining others' behavior.
The False Consensus Effect leads us to overestimate how much others agree with our views and behaviors.
Self-Serving Bias causes us to take credit for success but blame external factors for failure.
The Actor-Observer Effect describes how we attribute our own behavior to situations but others' behavior to dispositions.

content.text: The Fundamental Attribution Error (Ross, 1977)

The Fundamental Attribution Error (FAE) is the tendency to over-emphasize dispositional (personality-based) explanations for others' behavior while under-emphasizing situational influences. In other words, we tend to assume that what a person does reflects what 'kind' of person they are, rather than the social and environmental forces acting on them.

content.title: Ross, Amabile & Steinmetz (1977): The Quiz Game Study
content.text: Participants were randomly assigned to be questioners (who composed difficult questions) or contestants (who answered them). Despite knowing the roles were randomly assigned, both contestants and observers rated questioners as significantly more knowledgeable than contestants. This demonstrates the FAE: behavior was attributed to dispositional qualities (intelligence) rather than to the situational advantage (being able to choose the questions).

In the Quiz Game Study, questioners were rated as having 67-83 points of general knowledge, while contestants were rated at only 41-51 points, despite the role assignment being entirely random. This shows how powerfully we overestimate dispositional factors and underestimate situational factors.

content.title: Jones & Harris (1967): Castro Study
content.text: Participants listened to pro- and anti-Fidel Castro speeches. Even when explicitly told the speech position was determined by a coin flip (not the speaker's choice), participants still rated those who gave pro-Castro speeches as having more positive attitudes toward Castro. This demonstrates the FAE persists even when situational constraints are made obvious.
False Consensus Effect (Ross et al., 1977)
The False Consensus Effect is our tendency to overestimate the degree to which others share our beliefs, values, and behaviors. We see our own choices as more typical than they actually are.

In Ross, Greene & House's (1977) study, participants were asked if they would wear a sign around campus. Those who agreed to wear the sign estimated that 63% of others would also agree (actual rate: 50%). Those who refused estimated only 23% would agree (actual rate: 50%). Both groups overestimated how many others would behave as they did.
Self-Serving Bias (Miller & Ross, 1975)

The Self-Serving Bias is our tendency to take credit for success (self-enhancing bias) but deny responsibility for failure (self-protective bias). We make dispositional (internal) attributions for our successes and situational (external) attributions for our failures to protect and enhance self-esteem.
Examples include saying 'I got 90 for my essay!' (internal attribution) versus 'The lecturer gave me 40!' (external attribution). This bias serves to maintain positive self-esteem.
Actor-Observer Effect (Jones & Nisbett, 1972)

The Actor-Observer Effect describes how we attribute our own behavior to situational factors (when we are the actor) but attribute others' behavior to dispositional factors (when we are the observer).

For example, when YOU give a bad presentation, you know it was because you had three other projects due, your computer crashed, etc. (situational). When SOMEONE ELSE gives a bad presentation, you assume they don't know the subject well, lack intelligence, or are terrible at public speaking (dispositional).

content.title: Nisbett et al. (1973) Study
content.text: Male participants were asked 'Why did you choose your major?' and 'Why did your friend choose his major?' Actors (explaining their own choice) gave more situational reasons ('Engineering is a high-paying field'). Observers (explaining their friend's choice) gave more dispositional reasons ('My friend wants to make lots of money'). This shows the systematic actor-observer difference in attributions.

questions.question: What is the Fundamental Attribution Error?
options: Overemphasizing situational factors when explaining our own behavior
Overemphasizing dispositional factors when explaining others' behavior
Underestimating how much others agree with us
Taking credit for success but blaming others for failure
questions.answer: Overemphasizing dispositional factors when explaining others' behavior

explanation.correct: The FAE is the tendency to over-emphasize dispositional (personality-based) explanations for others' behavior while under-emphasizing situational influences on that behavior.

incorrect.Overemphasizing situational factors when: This describes part of the Actor-Observer Effect, not the Fundamental Attribution Error.
incorrect.Underestimating how much others agree wi: This is the opposite of the False Consensus Effect, which involves overestimating agreement.
incorrect.Taking credit for success but blaming ot: This describes the Self-Serving Bias, not the Fundamental Attribution Error.

questions.question: In the Quiz Game Study (Ross et al., 1977), why did contestants and observers rate questioners as more knowledgeable?
options: Questioners were actually more intelligent
They failed to account for the situational advantage of choosing questions
Contestants wanted to protect their self-esteem
Questioners studied more before the experiment
questions.answer: They failed to account for the situational advantage of choosing questions

explanation.correct: This demonstrates the Fundamental Attribution Error—participants attributed the questioners' performance to dispositional qualities (intelligence) rather than to the situational advantage of being able to select questions they knew answers to.

incorrect.Questioners were actually more intellige: Roles were randomly assigned, so there was no actual intelligence difference—this is the mistaken attribution participants made.
incorrect.Contestants wanted to protect their self: While contestants might have ego concerns, observers also made the same error, and the study measured ratings, not self-protection.
incorrect.Questioners studied more before the expe: There was no opportunity to study; the effect was due entirely to the situational role advantage.

questions.question: In the Castro Study (Jones & Harris, 1967), what did participants do even when told speech positions were determined by coin flip?
options: Correctly attributed speeches to chance
Still rated pro-Castro speakers as having more positive attitudes toward Castro
Refused to rate the speakers' attitudes
Rated anti-Castro speakers as more intelligent
questions.answer: Still rated pro-Castro speakers as having more positive attitudes toward Castro

explanation.correct: Even when explicitly told the speech position was determined randomly by coin flip, participants still committed the FAE and attributed the speech content to the speakers' true attitudes, ignoring the situational constraint.

incorrect.Correctly attributed speeches to chance: This would be the rational response, but participants did NOT do this—they still made dispositional attributions despite knowing about the coin flip.
incorrect.Refused to rate the speakers' attitudes: Participants completed the ratings as requested; they didn't refuse.
incorrect.Rated anti-Castro speakers as more intel: Intelligence wasn't measured; the study focused on inferred attitudes toward Castro.

questions.question: What is the False Consensus Effect?
options: Believing others always disagree with us
Overestimating how much others share our beliefs and behaviors
Underestimating our own abilities
Attributing success to luck
questions.answer: Overestimating how much others share our beliefs and behaviors

explanation.correct: The False Consensus Effect is our tendency to see our own behavior and choices as more typical than they actually are, overestimating the degree to which others agree with us.

incorrect.Believing others always disagree with us: This is the opposite of the False Consensus Effect—we actually overestimate agreement, not disagreement.
incorrect.Underestimating our own abilities: This relates more to self-esteem or self-efficacy issues, not the False Consensus Effect.
incorrect.Attributing success to luck: This would be an external attribution and relates more to Self-Serving Bias (or lack thereof).

questions.question: In Ross et al.'s (1977) sign-wearing study, what did participants who agreed to wear the sign estimate?
options: That 23% of others would also agree
That 50% of others would also agree
That 63% of others would also agree
That 77% of others would also agree
questions.answer: That 63% of others would also agree

explanation.correct: Those who agreed to wear the sign estimated 63% of others would agree (actual rate: 50%), demonstrating the False Consensus Effect—they overestimated how many would behave as they did.

incorrect.That 23% of others would also agree: This was the estimate made by those who REFUSED to wear the sign, not those who agreed.
incorrect.That 50% of others would also agree: This was the actual rate, not the overestimate made by those who agreed.
incorrect.That 77% of others would also agree: This was the estimate made by those who REFUSED (thinking 77% would also refuse), not by those who agreed.

questions.question: The Self-Serving Bias involves making what types of attributions?
options: Internal for failures, external for successes
Internal for successes, external for failures
External for both successes and failures
Internal for both successes and failures
questions.answer: Internal for successes, external for failures

explanation.correct: The Self-Serving Bias leads us to take credit for success with internal attributions ('I got 90!') but deny responsibility for failure with external attributions ('The lecturer gave me 40!'). This protects and enhances self-esteem.

incorrect.Internal for failures, external for succ: This is the opposite of the Self-Serving Bias and would harm rather than protect self-esteem.
incorrect.External for both successes and failures: This would show no bias; the Self-Serving Bias specifically involves different attributions for success vs. failure.
incorrect.Internal for both successes and failures: This would be consistent but not self-serving; the bias involves differential attributions.

questions.question: According to the Actor-Observer Effect, when YOU give a bad presentation, you attribute it to _____, but when SOMEONE ELSE gives a bad presentation, you attribute it to _____.
options: Situational factors; situational factors
Dispositional factors; dispositional factors
Situational factors; dispositional factors
Dispositional factors; situational factors
questions.answer: Situational factors; dispositional factors

explanation.correct: The Actor-Observer Effect means we attribute our own behavior (actor) to situational factors ('I had three projects due, my computer crashed') but others' behavior (observer) to dispositional factors ('They lack intelligence, poor public speaking skills').

incorrect.Situational factors; situational factors: This would show no actor-observer difference, but the effect specifically involves different attributions for self vs. others.
incorrect.Dispositional factors; dispositional fac: This would be consistent but ignores the systematic difference between how we explain our own vs. others' behavior.
incorrect.Dispositional factors; situational facto: This is the opposite of the Actor-Observer Effect—we are more generous with situational explanations for ourselves, not others.

questions.question: In Nisbett et al.'s (1973) study on major choice, actors gave _____ reasons for their own choice, while observers gave _____ reasons for their friend's choice.
options: Dispositional; situational
Situational; dispositional
Personal; personal
External; external
questions.answer: Situational; dispositional

explanation.correct: Actors explaining their own major choice gave situational reasons ('Engineering is a high-paying field'), while observers explaining their friend's choice gave dispositional reasons ('My friend wants to make lots of money'). This demonstrates the Actor-Observer Effect.

incorrect.Dispositional; situational: This is the opposite of what was found—the Actor-Observer Effect predicts situational for self, dispositional for others.
incorrect.Personal; personal: The key finding was the difference in attribution types, not similarity.
incorrect.External; external: While 'external' is similar to 'situational,' the pattern was specifically situational for actors and dispositional for observers, not external for both.

topics.title: Conformity and Social Influence
topics.subtitle: How Groups Shape Our Behavior
topics.summary: Conformity involves changing beliefs or behaviors to fit in with a group. Sherif's autokinetic effect study and Asch's line judgment experiments revealed different types of social influence: informational (desire to be correct) and normative (desire to be accepted).
keyTakeaways: Conformity can involve internalization (genuine belief change) or compliance (public agreement without private acceptance).
Sherif's study demonstrated informational social influence in ambiguous situations.
Asch's line studies showed normative social influence and the power of group pressure even in unambiguous situations.
Conformity increases with group size, decreases with dissenters, and varies by culture.

content.text: Defining Conformity
Conformity is a type of social influence involving a change in belief or behavior to fit in with a group. It can take two forms:

content.title: Types of Conformity
items: Internalization: Genuinely changing your real thoughts and feelings as a result of less direct pressure from others. Both public and private acceptance.
Compliance: Agreeing with others' opinions and complying with their requests publicly, but not changing your real internal opinions. Public agreement without private acceptance.

content.text: Sherif's (1935) Autokinetic Effect Experiment
Muzafer Sherif studied conformity using the autokinetic effect—when in total darkness, we perceive a small stationary bright light as moving (a perceptual illusion).

Participants first estimated how much the light moved when viewing it alone, then made estimates in groups of 2-3. Individual estimates converged toward a group norm. This demonstrates conformity in an ambiguous task where there is no objectively correct answer.

content.title: Informational Social Influence
content.text: Sherif's study demonstrates informational influence—we conform to information from others because it removes ambiguity and we desire to be correct. In ambiguous situations, we rely on others for information, leading to both public response and private acceptance (internalization).
Asch's (1950s) Line Judgment Experiments
Solomon Asch investigated conformity in an unambiguous task where the correct answer was obvious. Participants judged which of three comparison lines matched a standard line in length.

content.title: Asch's Procedure
items: Control group: 35 out of 37 people (95%) correctly judged the matching line, showing the task was unambiguous.
Experimental group: One real participant with 6-7 confederates (actors). Confederates were prearranged to give incorrect answers on certain trials.
Results: 37% of responses given by real participants were incorrect, conforming to the group. Participants showed extreme discomfort and reported fear of social disapproval.

content.title: Normative Social Influence
content.text: Asch's study demonstrates normative influence—we conform to be liked and accepted, even when we privately know the group is wrong. The situation is not ambiguous, but we seek social approval, resulting in public compliance without private acceptance.
Factors That Affect Conformity

content.title: Key Factors
items: Group Size: Conformity increases as group size increases, but levels off after about 3-5 people.
Presence of a Dissenter: Even one person disagreeing with the majority greatly reduces conformity. It breaks the unanimity of the group.
Culture: Conformity is greater in collectivistic cultures (which emphasize group harmony) compared to individualistic cultures.

content.text: Informational vs. Normative Social Influence
Two distinct processes drive conformity:

content.title: Comparison
items: Informational: Situation is ambiguous; participant relies on others for information; public response = private acceptance (internalization). Example: Sherif's study.
Normative: Situation is not ambiguous; participant seeks social approval; public response ≠ private acceptance (compliance). Example: Asch's study.

questions.question: What is the difference between internalization and compliance?
options: Internalization is public only; compliance is private only
Internalization involves genuine belief change; compliance is public agreement only
They are the same thing
Compliance is always stronger than internalization
questions.answer: Internalization involves genuine belief change; compliance is public agreement only

explanation.correct: Internalization means genuinely changing your thoughts and feelings (both public and private acceptance), while compliance means agreeing publicly without changing your private beliefs.

incorrect.Internalization is public only; complian: This is backward—internalization is both public and private, while compliance is only public.
incorrect.They are the same thing: These are distinct types of conformity with different underlying processes and outcomes.
incorrect.Compliance is always stronger than inter: Actually, internalization is more enduring because it involves genuine belief change, not just surface compliance.

questions.question: What is the autokinetic effect used in Sherif's (1935) study?
options: A stationary light appears to move in total darkness
A moving light appears stationary
Lines appear different lengths
Shapes appear to have personalities
questions.answer: A stationary light appears to move in total darkness

explanation.correct: The autokinetic effect is a perceptual illusion where a stationary point of light in complete darkness appears to move due to small, involuntary eye movements.

incorrect.A moving light appears stationary: This is the opposite of the autokinetic effect.
incorrect.Lines appear different lengths: This describes visual illusions like the Müller-Lyer illusion, not the autokinetic effect. Lines were used in Asch's study, not Sherif's.
incorrect.Shapes appear to have personalities: This describes Heider and Simmel's attribution study with geometric shapes, not Sherif's conformity study.

questions.question: In Sherif's study, what happened to individual estimates when participants made judgments in groups?
options: They became more diverse and varied
They remained exactly the same
They converged toward a group norm
They became random
questions.answer: They converged toward a group norm

explanation.correct: Individual estimates that varied when judging alone converged toward a group norm when participants made estimates together, demonstrating informational social influence in an ambiguous situation.

incorrect.They became more diverse and varied: This is the opposite of what happened—estimates converged and became more similar, not more diverse.
incorrect.They remained exactly the same: If estimates stayed the same, there would be no conformity. The key finding was that they changed to become more similar.
incorrect.They became random: Estimates didn't become random; they systematically converged on a shared group norm.

questions.question: In Asch's line judgment studies, what percentage of the control group correctly identified the matching line?

explanation.correct: 35 out of 37 participants (95%) in the control group correctly judged the matching line, demonstrating that the task was unambiguous and the correct answer was obvious.

incorrect.37%: This was the percentage of INCORRECT responses in the experimental group (showing conformity), not correct responses in the control group.
incorrect.65%: This is the percentage from Milgram's obedience study (who went to maximum shock), not related to Asch's control group.
incorrect.75%: This is not a key figure from Asch's study; 95% is the correct control group accuracy.

questions.question: What percentage of responses in Asch's experimental group conformed to the incorrect majority?

explanation.correct: 37% of responses given by real participants conformed to the confederates' incorrect answers, despite the correct answer being obvious. This shows the power of normative social influence.

incorrect.12%: This underestimates the conformity rate found in Asch's study.
incorrect.25%: While substantial, the actual rate was higher at 37%.
incorrect.50%: This overestimates the conformity rate; while high, it wasn't half of all responses.

questions.question: What type of social influence does Sherif's study demonstrate?
options: Normative social influence
Informational social influence
Obedience to authority
Group polarization
questions.answer: Informational social influence

explanation.correct: Sherif's study with the ambiguous autokinetic effect demonstrates informational social influence—participants relied on others for information to reduce uncertainty and determine the 'correct' answer.

incorrect.Normative social influence: This is demonstrated by Asch's unambiguous line study, where people conform for social approval despite knowing the answer.
incorrect.Obedience to authority: This describes Milgram's studies where participants followed direct orders from an authority figure, not peer conformity.
incorrect.Group polarization: This refers to groups making more extreme decisions than individuals would, not the conformity process in Sherif's study.

questions.question: Why did participants in Asch's study report conforming to the incorrect group answer?
options: They genuinely couldn't see the correct line
They feared social disapproval
They thought the task was ambiguous
They were instructed to conform
questions.answer: They feared social disapproval

explanation.correct: Participants showed extreme discomfort and reported fear of social disapproval as the reason for conforming. This demonstrates normative influence—conforming to be accepted even when privately knowing the group is wrong.

incorrect.They genuinely couldn't see the correct: The control group's 95% accuracy shows the task was obvious. Participants knew the answer but conformed anyway.
incorrect.They thought the task was ambiguous: The task was clearly unambiguous—this is what distinguishes Asch's study (normative influence) from Sherif's (informational influence).
incorrect.They were instructed to conform: There were no instructions to conform; the conformity arose from social pressure, making it a more powerful demonstration.

questions.question: Which of the following factors REDUCES conformity in Asch-type situations?
options: Increasing group size from 3 to 10 people
Having even one person dissent from the majority
Making the task more ambiguous
Testing in collectivistic cultures
questions.answer: Having even one person dissent from the majority

explanation.correct: Even one person disagreeing with the majority greatly reduces conformity because it breaks the unanimity of the group and provides social support for the correct answer.

incorrect.Increasing group size from 3 to 10 peopl: This would increase, not decrease, conformity (though the effect levels off after 3-5 people).
incorrect.Making the task more ambiguous: Ambiguity increases conformity because people rely more on others when uncertain.
incorrect.Testing in collectivistic cultures: Collectivistic cultures show HIGHER conformity rates because they emphasize group harmony over individual opinion.

topics.title: Obedience to Authority
topics.subtitle: Following Orders from Authority Figures
topics.summary: Obedience is a form of social influence where individuals act in response to direct orders from authority figures. Milgram's shocking experiments and Zimbardo's Stanford Prison Experiment revealed how easily ordinary people can be led to harm others when instructed by perceived authorities.
keyTakeaways: Milgram's shock experiments showed 65% of participants administered the maximum 450-volt shock when ordered by an authority figure.
Obedience persists even when causing visible distress to victims and conflicts with personal morality.
Follow-up studies (Hofling's nurses, Sheridan & King's puppy study) replicated high obedience in real-world settings.
Zimbardo's Stanford Prison Experiment demonstrated how situational roles and authority can lead to abusive behavior.

content.text: What is Obedience?

Obedience is a form of social influence where an individual acts in response to a direct order from another individual, usually an authority figure. It is assumed that without such an order, the person would not have acted in that way.
Milgram's (1963-1974) Shock Generator Studies

Stanley Milgram conducted one of the most famous and controversial studies in psychology to understand how ordinary people could commit atrocities when ordered by authorities (motivated by trying to understand the Holocaust).

content.title: Milgram's Procedure
items: Participants believed they were in a study on 'the effects of punishment on learning behavior.'
Participants were assigned to be the 'teacher' (the role was actually rigged). A confederate was always the 'learner.'
The teacher administered electric shocks to the learner for each wrong answer, increasing the voltage with each error.
Shocks ranged from 15 volts ('Slight Shock') to 450 volts ('XXX' - beyond 'Danger: Severe Shock').
In reality, no shocks were given—the learner (confederate) acted as though in pain.

content.title: The Learner's Responses
content.text: At 300 volts, the learner banged on the wall and complained of a heart condition. After this, the learner gave no further responses. Many teachers wanted to stop, but the experimenter gave standardized prods: 'Please continue,' 'The experiment requires that you continue,' 'You have no other choice, you must go on.'
Milgram's Shocking Results

Before the study, Milgram asked fellow psychologists to predict the results. They estimated that only sadistic individuals would administer maximum voltage. The actual results were dramatically different:

content.title: Obedience Rates
items: 65% (26 out of 40) of participants administered the maximum 450-volt shock.
100% of participants went to at least 300 volts (the point where the learner banged on the wall).
Average maximum shock level was 360 volts.
Many participants showed extreme stress—trembling, sweating, nervous laughter—but continued when prompted by the authority figure.

content.title: Breakdown of Final Shock Levels
content.text: 300V: 5 people stopped (12.5%). 315V: 4 people (10%). 330V: 2 people (5%). 345-375V: 3 people total (7.5%). 450V (maximum): 26 people (65%) administered the full shock.
Follow-Up Studies: Real-World Obedience
Critics argued Milgram's setup was artificial. Follow-up studies tested obedience in more realistic settings:

content.title: Hofling et al. (1966): Nurses and Lethal Injections
content.text: In a hospital setting, 21 out of 22 nurses prepared to administer a potentially lethal injection to patients when ordered by an unknown doctor over the phone, despite official guidelines forbidding such administration. This study had high ecological validity and showed obedience occurs in real professional contexts.

content.title: Sheridan & King (1972): Puppy Study
content.text: Participants were asked to give REAL (but small) electric shocks to a puppy for a learning task. Participants obeyed even though they could directly see the distress of the animal, eliminating doubts about whether Milgram's participants truly believed they were giving shocks.
Zimbardo's Stanford Prison Experiment (1973)
Philip Zimbardo's Stanford Prison Experiment demonstrated aspects of conformity, obedience, and the power of social situations on behavior.

content.title: SPE Procedure and Results
items: College student volunteers were randomly assigned to be 'guards' or 'prisoners' in a simulated prison in the basement of Stanford's psychology building.
Guards quickly became authoritarian, enforcing harsh rules and humiliating prisoners (e.g., stripping, delousing, sleep deprivation).
Prisoners showed passive submission, anxiety, emotional breakdowns, and some rebellion.
The planned 2-week study was terminated after only 6 days due to ethical concerns over escalating abuse and emotional harm.
Guards' behavior was not explicitly ordered but emerged from the situational role and implicit authority.

content.title: Key Lesson
content.text: The SPE demonstrates that situational factors and assigned roles can powerfully shape behavior, leading ordinary people to behave in cruel ways without explicit orders. The power of the situation and perceived authority can override personal values.

questions.question: What is obedience in the context of social influence?
options: Changing behavior to fit in with a group
Acting in response to a direct order from an authority figure
Privately accepting group norms
Helping others in need
questions.answer: Acting in response to a direct order from an authority figure

explanation.correct: Obedience is a form of social influence where an individual acts in response to a direct order from an authority figure. Without the order, the person would not have acted that way.

incorrect.Changing behavior to fit in with a group: This describes conformity, not obedience. Conformity involves peer pressure, while obedience involves direct orders from authority.
incorrect.Privately accepting group norms: This describes internalization, a type of conformity, not obedience to authority.
incorrect.Helping others in need: This describes prosocial behavior or altruism, not obedience.

questions.question: In Milgram's shock experiment, what percentage of participants administered the maximum 450-volt shock?

explanation.correct: 65% (26 out of 40) of participants administered the experiment's final 450-volt shock, far exceeding predictions that only sadistic individuals would do so.

incorrect.10%: This severely underestimates the shocking level of obedience found in Milgram's study.
incorrect.37%: This is the conformity rate from Asch's line studies, not the obedience rate from Milgram's shock studies.
incorrect.50%: While this would still be high, the actual rate was even higher at 65%.

questions.question: At what voltage level did the learner in Milgram's study bang on the wall and complain of a heart condition?
options: 150 volts
225 volts
300 volts
450 volts
questions.answer: 300 volts

explanation.correct: At 300 volts, the learner banged on the wall and complained of a heart condition. After this point, the learner gave no further responses, yet 100% of participants continued to at least this level.

incorrect.150 volts: This was an earlier point in the sequence but not when the learner banged on the wall.
incorrect.225 volts: This is also earlier in the sequence; the critical wall-banging occurred at 300 volts.
incorrect.450 volts: This was the maximum shock level, but the learner's wall-banging and heart complaint occurred much earlier at 300 volts.

questions.question: Before conducting his study, Milgram asked psychologists to predict the results. What did they predict?
options: That 65% would give maximum shocks
That only sadistic individuals would give maximum shocks
That all participants would refuse to continue
That 50% would give maximum shocks
questions.answer: That only sadistic individuals would give maximum shocks

explanation.correct: Fellow psychologists predicted that only sadistic individuals would administer the maximum voltage, drastically underestimating the power of situational factors and authority. The actual 65% rate shocked the research community.

incorrect.That 65% would give maximum shocks: This was the actual result, not the prediction. Experts expected much lower obedience.
incorrect.That all participants would refuse to co: While experts expected low obedience, they didn't predict complete refusal from everyone.
incorrect.That 50% would give maximum shocks: This specific prediction wasn't made; experts predicted only pathological individuals would fully obey.

questions.question: In Hofling et al.'s (1966) nurse study, how many nurses prepared to administer a potentially lethal injection when ordered by phone?
options: 5 out of 22
11 out of 22
16 out of 22
21 out of 22
questions.answer: 21 out of 22

explanation.correct: 21 out of 22 nurses prepared to give a potentially lethal injection despite official guidelines forbidding it, demonstrating that high obedience occurs in real professional settings, not just laboratory experiments.

incorrect.5 out of 22: This severely underestimates the obedience rate found in the study.
incorrect.11 out of 22: This would be 50%, but the actual rate was much higher at over 95%.
incorrect.16 out of 22: While high, the actual rate was even higher at 21 out of 22.

questions.question: What was significant about Sheridan & King's (1972) puppy study?
options: It used lower voltage shocks than Milgram
Participants gave REAL shocks and could see the animal's distress
No one obeyed the experimenter
It was conducted with children
questions.answer: Participants gave REAL shocks and could see the animal's distress

explanation.correct: This study eliminated doubts about whether Milgram's participants truly believed they were giving shocks. Participants gave REAL (though small) shocks to a puppy and could directly see its distress, yet still obeyed. This strengthens Milgram's findings.

incorrect.It used lower voltage shocks than Milgra: While true, the significance is that the shocks were REAL and the distress was visible, not just the voltage level.
incorrect.No one obeyed the experimenter: This is the opposite of what happened—participants did obey despite seeing real distress.
incorrect.It was conducted with children: The study used adult participants, not children. The 'puppy' was the victim receiving shocks, not the participant.

questions.question: Zimbardo's Stanford Prison Experiment was terminated after how many days (instead of the planned 2 weeks)?
options: 2 days
6 days
10 days
14 days
questions.answer: 6 days

explanation.correct: The study was terminated after only 6 days (instead of 2 weeks) due to ethical concerns over escalating abuse and emotional breakdowns among participants.

incorrect.2 days: The study ran longer than 2 days before being stopped.
incorrect.10 days: The study was stopped earlier than this due to the severity of the situation.
incorrect.14 days: This was the planned duration, but the study was terminated early after 6 days.

questions.question: In the Stanford Prison Experiment, what behaviors did the guards exhibit?
options: They refused to enforce rules
They became authoritarian and enforced harsh rules with humiliation
They treated prisoners with kindness
They quit the experiment early
questions.answer: They became authoritarian and enforced harsh rules with humiliation

explanation.correct: Guards quickly became authoritarian, enforcing harsh rules and humiliating prisoners through stripping, delousing, sleep deprivation, and other degrading treatments, demonstrating how situational roles can shape behavior.

incorrect.They refused to enforce rules: This is the opposite of what happened—guards became increasingly strict and abusive.
incorrect.They treated prisoners with kindness: Guards became cruel and authoritarian, not kind, showing the dark side of authority and power.
incorrect.They quit the experiment early: Guards continued in their roles; it was the researchers who terminated the experiment due to ethical concerns.

questions.question: What is the key lesson from both Milgram's and Zimbardo's studies?
options: Only evil people commit harmful acts
Personality determines behavior more than situations
Situational factors and authority can lead ordinary people to harmful behavior
People always resist authority when it conflicts with morals
questions.answer: Situational factors and authority can lead ordinary people to harmful behavior

explanation.correct: Both studies demonstrate the power of situations and perceived authority to lead ordinary, non-pathological people to behave in harmful ways they wouldn't normally choose. This challenges the 'bad apple' theory and highlights situational power.

incorrect.Only evil people commit harmful acts: This is exactly what these studies disproved—ordinary people committed harmful acts when placed in certain situations with authority pressure.
incorrect.Personality determines behavior more tha: This is the opposite lesson—the studies showed that situations can override personality and personal values.
incorrect.People always resist authority when it c: These studies showed that people often DON'T resist authority even when it conflicts with their morals, which is what made the findings so disturbing.
